terms.definition: Method of placing components directly onto the surface of a PCB, contrasting with Through-Hole Technology (THT)
Older method where component leads pass through holes in the PCB and are soldered on the opposite side
Temperature at which PCB material transitions from rigid to soft/rubbery state
Temperature at which PCB resin chemically breaks down
Measure of how much a material slows down electromagnetic waves
Measure of signal loss in a dielectric material
Rate at which a material expands with temperature, measured in ppm/°C
Duration the solder is above its melting point during reflow
Compound formed at the interface between solder and copper (e.g., Cu₆Sn₅)
Family of lead-free solder alloys (e.g., SAC305 = Sn96.5/Ag3.0/Cu0.5)
EU directive restricting use of hazardous materials including lead in electronics
Alloy composition with lowest melting point that melts/solidifies at a single temperature (no pasty range)
Temperature range where solder is partially liquid and partially solid
Property of solder paste that makes it thin under stress (squeegee) but thick at rest
Aperture width divided by stencil thickness. Must be >1.5 for good paste release
Aperture opening area divided by aperture wall area. Must be >0.66 for good paste release
3D inspection of solder paste deposits after printing, before component placement
Camera-based inspection of assembled boards for defects
X-ray inspection for hidden solder joints (BGAs, QFNs)
IC package with solder balls on the bottom surface
Leadless IC package with pads on the bottom
IC package with leads on all four sides
PCB surface finish with nickel barrier and thin gold coating
PCB surface finish where molten solder is applied and excess blown off
Thin organic coating that protects copper pads from oxidation
Defect where chip component stands up vertically on one end
BGA defect where ball rests on paste but doesn't merge due to oxidation
Defect where solder looks like cluster of un-melted grapes due to flux exhaustion
IC package cracking due to moisture turning to steam during reflow
Copper marker on PCB used by pick-and-place machines for alignment
Measure of how flat component leads are relative to each other
Ability of molten solder to flow and adhere to a surface
Dissolution of copper pad into molten solder during extended reflow
ENIG defect where high phosphorus in nickel causes brittle joints
Crystalline structures that grow from tin surfaces and can cause shorts
PCB with metal (usually aluminum) backing for thermal management
Circuit made on flexible substrate (usually polyimide)

standards.name: J-STD-001
standards.title: Requirements for Soldered Electrical and Electronic Assemblies
standards.description: The 'Law' - Defines materials and process requirements

standards.name: IPC-A-610
standards.title: Acceptability of Electronic Assemblies
standards.description: The 'Picture Book' - Visual standards for inspectors

standards.name: IPC-7525
standards.title: Stencil Design Guidelines
standards.description: Math behind aperture sizes and area ratios

standards.name: IPC-7095
standards.title: Design and Assembly Process Implementation for BGAs
standards.description: The bible for Ball Grid Arrays and voiding criteria

standards.name: IPC-9701
standards.title: Performance Test Methods for Solder Attachment
standards.description: How to thermal cycle and stress test solder bonds

standards.name: J-STD-033
standards.title: Handling, Packing, Shipping and Use of Moisture Sensitive Devices
standards.description: Standard for moisture sensitivity levels and baking requirements

standards.name: J-STD-004
standards.title: Requirements for Soldering Fluxes
standards.description: Classification and requirements for flux materials

standards.name: J-STD-005
standards.title: Requirements for Soldering Pastes
standards.description: Classification of solder paste powder types
